Problem:
Assume a linear system described by the equation \(\dot{z} = Mz\), where \(M\) is a linear operator. We examine the role of a transformation initiated by \(\Gamma(z) = Qz\), \(Q\) being another linear operator, applied at an initial time \(t = 0\).

If, after initiating the system at \(z_0\) and applying \(\Gamma(z) = Qz\), a deliberate intervention \(\Xi(z) = Pz\) (where \(P\) is another linear operator) is applied at time \(t_1\), will the state \(z(T)\) for \(T > t_1\) depend only on \(M\) and not on \(Q\) or \(P\)?
Explanation: The endpoint \(z(T)\) will be influenced by the interventions from \(Q\) and \(P\) as well as the original operator \(M\). The interactions of \(Q\), \(P\), and \(M\), particularly how they modify the system trajectory through their respective transformations, make \(z(T)\) a function of all these elements, not just \(M\).
